main.name: Honeypot Attack Visualizer
main.description: CS 426 Senior Project in Computer Science, Spring 2021, at UNR, CSE Department
main.bio: The Honeypot Attack Visualizer is designed to provide users with real time data on locations and variations of attacks           that are occurring around the world. The data from the honeypots is displayed on a web based application that provides           users with a map and options to control what data types they prefer to be visualized. The data is collected through the          utilization of multiple honeypots located in several cities around the world that log all incoming attacks. These data           entries range from attacks directed at specific honeypots, the number of attacks, and a specific date or a range of              dates. The intended users are cybersecurity professionals or organizations looking to understand the many different              attack attempts that exist in the world. It would benefit experts by providing insight on potential threats that may             target their systems in the future along with their origins. For the general public, the visualization would provide an          estimate or sample of the many cyber attacks that exist through an interactive web application. The Honeypot Attack              Visualizer utilizes a variety of technologies to provide users with engaging visualization of attacks. For the                   front-end, the map and its options are displayed using React, Deck.gl, Google Maps, and Mapbox. The map receives data            from a database server that runs on MySQL and conducts automated daily updates of honeypot data through the use of                Python scripts.
main.contactmessage: Here is where you should write your message to readers to have them get in contact with you.

book.title: Intrusion Detection Honeypots: Detection through Deception
book.author: Chris Sanders
book.description: A great read the provides a detialed overview of honeypots and how they are beneficial for intrustion detection. The book specifically covers how honeypots can be used to mimic services such as HTTP, SSH, and RDP. Additionally, tips on monitoring honeypots and how to use the their logs to conduct anaylsis are covered which is one of main challenges that the Honeypot Attack Visualizer is trying to cover.

paper.title: Causal analysis of attacks against honeypots based on properties of countries
paper.citation: Zuzcak, Matej & Bujok, Petr. (2019). Causal analysis of attacks against honeypots based on properties of countries. IET Information Security. 10.1049/iet-ifs.2018.5141.

paper.title: Discovering Hackers by Stealth: Predicting Fingerprinting Attacks on Honeypot Systems
paper.citation: N. Naik and P. Jenkins, Discovering Hackers by Stealth: Predicting Fingerprinting Attacks on Honeypot Systems, 2018 IEEE International Systems Engineering Symposium (ISSE), Rome, 2018, pp. 1-8, doi: 10.1109/SysEng.2018.8544408.

paper.title: Study of attack using honeypots and honeynets lessons learned from time-oriented visualization
paper.citation: P. Sokol, L. Kleinová and M. Husák, Study of attack using honeypots and honeynets lessons learned from time-oriented visualization, IEEE EUROCON 2015 - International Conference on Computer as a Tool (EUROCON), Salamanca, 2015, pp. 1-6, doi: 10.1109/EUROCON.2015.7313713.

paper.title: Tracking attack sources based on traceback honeypot for ICS network
paper.citation: S. Abe, Y. Tanaka, Y. Uchida and S. Horata, Tracking attack sources based on traceback honeypot for ICS network, 2017 56th Annual Conference of the Society of Instrument and Control Engineers of Japan (SICE), Kanazawa, 2017, pp. 717-723, doi: 10.23919/SICE.2017.8105603.
